content.body:
> <@miketayl_r:mozilla.org> sideshowbarker: i guess we could include some text for given entries in compat like, prefer this standard thing instead (not sure how useful that is, but it wouldn't be hard)

Yeah, I vote for that
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @miketayl_r:mozilla.org
sideshowbarker: i guess we could include some text for given entries in compat like, prefer this standard thing instead (not sure how useful that is, but it wouldn't be hard)
Yeah, I vote for that

content.body: Compat spec has been conceived as a transition document. Nothing in there should be considered the source of truth. It just **attempts** to document things that need to be taken elsewhere in a proper spec **if the spec wants to take it on**.
content.formatted_body: Compat spec has been conceived as a transition document. Nothing in there should be considered the source of truth. It just attempts to document things that need to be taken elsewhere in a proper spec if the spec wants to take it on.

content.body: And yes having section pointing to the right place when it has been described in a proper spec would be great.

sideshowbarker: 

> or is it the case that pretty much everything in the Compat spec should be considered discouraged/deprecated?
content.formatted_body:
sideshowbarker:

or is it the case that pretty much everything in the Compat spec should be considered discouraged/deprecated?

content.body: do you mean on the authoring side of things?
Definitely everything which is mentioned in compat spec should not be perceived as ok to write code.
howdy karlcow yeah I meant strictly the author side of things
content.formatted_body: howdy karlcow yeah I meant strictly the author side of things

content.body: My HTML parser is 1400 lines and *still* fails to implement a *lot* of the parsing spec. That is one really long spec xD. My parser is worth about 14% of my project's code. Wow, that spec is long
content.formatted_body: My HTML parser is 1400 lines and still fails to implement a lot of the parsing spec. That is one really long spec xD. My parser is worth about 14% of my project's code. Wow, that spec is long

content.body: Tokei tells me that html5lib-python is ~13,000 lines of Python code (exclusing comments, but including the test harness and so on)
Weirdly html5ever has the same number of lines of Rust to within 2%
The validator.nu HTML parser seems to be about 28,000 lines of Java (also including infrastructure, etc.)

Wow, that's giant
Looks like I got my work cut out.
(I still need to learn Rust btw)

My unit tests also completely fail to exist
So I will have to write those someday.

> <@jgraham_:matrix.org> You know about https://github.com/html5lib/html5lib-tests/ ?

No
But I do know about https://wpt.live/
I'll have to star that other one.
